org.sakaiproject.genericdao.springjdbc
Class SimpleDataMapper

java.lang.Object
  org.sakaiproject.genericdao.springjdbc.SimpleDataMapper
All Implemented Interfaces:
DataMapper
public class SimpleDataMapper
extends Object
implements DataMapper

This class allows us to generate a DataMapper using Spring or anything else that can set/inject strings to create an object, most of the functions are assumed to be handled automatically by generic DAO

Author:
Aaron Zeckoski (azeckoski@gmail.com)

Constructor Summary

SimpleDataMapper(Class<?> persistentType)
          This is primarily for use when using all gendao conventions and annotations with a class, otherwise this will not include enough information to complete the mapping, the tablename will be the classname if no annotation is used, the id column must be ID if no annotation is used and the property must also be id

 void setDBTypeToDDL(Map<String,String> dbTypeToDDL)
          (REQUIRED/OPTIONAL) Sets the map of databaseTypeConstant -> DDL, these will be appended to any existing values
This must be set if the table does not already exist but if it does then this is optional
The first non-comment ('--') line will be run, and if successful, all other non-comment lines will be run.
 void setDBTypeToFile(Map<String,String> dbTypeToFile)
          (REQUIRED/OPTIONAL) Sets the map of databaseTypeConstant -> file containing the DDL script, the DDL will be looked up and stored in the class and executed on service init
This must be set if the table does not already exist but if it does then this is optional
The first non-comment ('--') line will be run, and if successful, all other non-comment lines will be run.
 void setIdPropertyName(String idPropertyName)
          (OPTIONAL) This is the name of the property on the persistent object which defines the unique identifier, defaults to null if unset but that will be replaced by the proper id or the default of "id"
 void setNamesMapping(Map<String,String> namesMapping)
          (OPTIONAL) Set this to a map of the persistent object properties to database column names, String -> String,
example: "id" -> "ID", "title" -> "ITEM_TITLE"
defaults to autogenerated column names which are uppercased and underscored (as in example above)
 void setNamesRecord(NamesRecord namesRecord)
          (OPTIONAL) Set the NamesRecord used for this mapping directly, this controls the mapping of object properties to database columns, this is more work than is probably needed but allows the most control, see the other methods
 void setNamesUsed(String[] namesUsed)
          (OPTIONAL) Set this to an array of the persistent object properties which will be used for this mapping, anything not listed will be ignored when forming queries, this is the least work but depends on the more conventions and allows the least control
NOTE: Be sure to set setUsePropertyNamesForColumns(boolean) before calling this method
Example: ["id", "title"],
"id" -> "ID", "title" -> "ITEM_TITLE"
defaults to autogenerated column names which are uppercased and underscored (as in example above) depending on the setting for isUsePropertyNamesForColumns()
 void setPersistentClassname(String persistentClassname)
          (REQUIRED) set this to the class name (e.g. org.project.MyClass) and it will be converted into the class object
 void setPersistentType(Class<?> persistentType)
          Allows setting the persistent type, this should normally be done in the constructor and cannot be changed once it has been set
 void setTableName(String tableName)
          (OPTIONAL) set this to the name of the table,
defaults to a name built from the simple class name of the persistent class
 void setUsePropertyNamesForColumns(boolean usePropertyNamesForColumns)
          (OPTIONAL) This will cause the mapper to use the property names as is (case and characters) for the columns names instead of transforming them (e.g. property: myThing => column: myThing), default is false (that means property: myThing => column: MY_THING)

Constructor Detail

SimpleDataMapper

public SimpleDataMapper()
Default constructor which is used by Spring mostly, you will need to at least set the

SimpleDataMapper

public SimpleDataMapper(Class<?> persistentType)
This is primarily for use when using all gendao conventions and annotations with a class, otherwise this will not include enough information to complete the mapping, the tablename will be the classname if no annotation is used, the id column must be ID if no annotation is used and the property must also be id

Parameters:
persistentType - any class type to map as a persistent type

SimpleDataMapper

public SimpleDataMapper(Class<?> persistentType,
                        String idPropertyName,
                        String tableName)
This is useful when adhering to some of the gendao conventions but needing to specify your own id property and tableName

Parameters:
persistentType - any class type to map as a persistent type
idPropertyName - this is the property name matching the identifier for the table
tableName - this is the name of the table that matches this persistent class

isUsePropertyNamesForColumns

public boolean isUsePropertyNamesForColumns()

setUsePropertyNamesForColumns

public void setUsePropertyNamesForColumns(boolean usePropertyNamesForColumns)
(OPTIONAL) This will cause the mapper to use the property names as is (case and characters) for the columns names instead of transforming them (e.g. property: myThing => column: myThing), default is false (that means property: myThing => column: MY_THING)

setIdPropertyName

public void setIdPropertyName(String idPropertyName)
(OPTIONAL) This is the name of the property on the persistent object which defines the unique identifier, defaults to null if unset but that will be replaced by the proper id or the default of "id"

getIdPropertyName

public String getIdPropertyName()
Description copied from interface: DataMapper
Specify the value which is the unique id for this persistent object, normally the values on this property should be assigned by the database (e.g. autoincrement)

Specified by:
getIdPropertyName in interface DataMapper
Returns:
the name of the identifier property from the persistent object OR return null to use the default "id"

setPersistentType

public void setPersistentType(Class<?> persistentType)
Allows setting the persistent type, this should normally be done in the constructor and cannot be changed once it has been set

Parameters:
persistentType - this is the class that maps to the DB table
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the input is null or the value is already set

Parameters:
persistentClassname - this is the fully qualified classname of the persistent type

getTableName in interface DataMapper
Returns:
the name of the table where these persistent objects are stored OR return null to have generic dao generate the name from the classname

setNamesMapping

public void setNamesMapping(Map<String,String> namesMapping)
(OPTIONAL) Set this to a map of the persistent object properties to database column names, String -> String,
example: "id" -> "ID", "title" -> "ITEM_TITLE"
defaults to autogenerated column names which are uppercased and underscored (as in example above)

See Also:
setNamesUsed(String[]), setNamesRecord(NamesRecord)

setNamesUsed

public void setNamesUsed(String[] namesUsed)
(OPTIONAL) Set this to an array of the persistent object properties which will be used for this mapping, anything not listed will be ignored when forming queries, this is the least work but depends on the more conventions and allows the least control
NOTE: Be sure to set setUsePropertyNamesForColumns(boolean) before calling this method
Example: ["id", "title"],
"id" -> "ID", "title" -> "ITEM_TITLE"
defaults to autogenerated column names which are uppercased and underscored (as in example above) depending on the setting for isUsePropertyNamesForColumns()

See Also:
setNamesMapping(Map), setNamesRecord(NamesRecord)

setNamesRecord

public void setNamesRecord(NamesRecord namesRecord)
(OPTIONAL) Set the NamesRecord used for this mapping directly, this controls the mapping of object properties to database columns, this is more work than is probably needed but allows the most control, see the other methods

See Also:
setNamesMapping(Map), setNamesUsed(String[])

getPropertyToColumnNamesMapping

public NamesRecord getPropertyToColumnNamesMapping()
Description copied from interface: DataMapper
Defines the mapping between persistent entity properties and database column names, NOTE: auto generate will surely fail if you did not use the standard UPPERCASE and underscore to create your column names in your DDL (e.g. "myThing" -> "MY_THING")

Specified by:
getPropertyToColumnNamesMapping in interface DataMapper
Returns:
a NamesRecord OR return null to have generic dao generate the mapping using reflection

getDbTypeToDDL

public Map<String,String> getDbTypeToDDL()

addDBTypeAndDDL

public void addDBTypeAndDDL(String databaseTypeConstant,
                            String ddl)
Convenience method which allows setting the DDL for a database type, this will be appended to existing entries
Generally only useful if you only need to set a single DDL

Parameters:
databaseTypeConstant - one of the database type constants from, e.g. DataMapper.DBTYPE_MYSQL, this indicates which database your DDL should work for
ddl - the ddl to execute to create the table(s) for this persistent object

getDbTypeToFilename

public Map<String,String> getDbTypeToFilename()

setDBTypeToFile

public void setDBTypeToFile(Map<String,String> dbTypeToFile)
(REQUIRED/OPTIONAL) Sets the map of databaseTypeConstant -> file containing the DDL script, the DDL will be looked up and stored in the class and executed on service init
This must be set if the table does not already exist but if it does then this is optional
The first non-comment ('--') line will be run, and if successful, all other non-comment lines will be run. SQL statements may be on multiple lines but must have ';' terminators.
Can use the makeDDLTypeMap(String, String[]) method to make this more easily
The following keys will be replaced automatically:
{TABLENAME} - the value returned by getTableName()
{ID} - the column name of the unique identifier
{IDSEQNAME} - (Oracle) a sequence name will be generated and inserted based on the tablename for use in generating IDs, if you want to specify your own sequence name then you will lose the ability to have the ID inserted into newly created objects
NOTE: the file must be in your jar/war/package so it can be located in the classloader, use something like this in your maven pom.xml resources tag: <resource> <directory>${basedir}/src/sql</directory> <includes> <include>** /*.sql</include> </includes> </resource> Remove the space between ** and /* from the above sample
For example: src/sql/mysql.sql, src/sql/mysql/myproject.ddl

See Also:
setDBTypeToDDL(Map), makeDDLTypeMap(String, String[])

setDBTypeToDDL

public void setDBTypeToDDL(Map<String,String> dbTypeToDDL)
(REQUIRED/OPTIONAL) Sets the map of databaseTypeConstant -> DDL, these will be appended to any existing values
This must be set if the table does not already exist but if it does then this is optional
The first non-comment ('--') line will be run, and if successful, all other non-comment lines will be run. SQL statements may be on multiple lines but must have ';' terminators.
The following keys will be replaced automatically:
{TABLENAME} - the value returned by getTableName()
{ID} - the column name of the unique identifier
{IDSEQNAME} - (Oracle) a sequence name will be generated and inserted based on the tablename for use in generating IDs, if you want to specify your own sequence name then you will lose the ability to have the ID inserted into newly created objects

See Also:
setDBTypeToFile(Map)

generateDDL

public String generateDDL(String databaseTypeConstant)
Description copied from interface: DataMapper
Called when the JDBC generic dao beans are first starting up, if the first line fails then the rest of the file is ignored, this means you should normally include the create table statement first
The first non-comment ('--') line will be run, and if successful, all other non-comment lines will be run. SQL statements may be on multiple lines but must have ';' terminators.
The following keys will be replaced automatically:
{TABLENAME} - the value returned by DataMapper.getTableName()
{ID} - the column name of the unique identifier
{TABLENAME:org.domain.MyClass} - the value returned by DataMapper.getTableName() for the persistent type MyClass
{ID:org.domain.MyClass} - the column name of the unique identifier for the persistent type MyClass
{IDSEQNAME} - (Oracle) a sequence name will be generated and inserted based on the tablename for use in generating IDs, if you want to specify your own sequence name then you will lose the ability to have the ID inserted into newly created objects

Specified by:
generateDDL in interface DataMapper
Parameters:
databaseTypeConstant - one of the database type constants from, e.g. DataMapper.DBTYPE_MYSQL, this indicates which database your DDL should work for, you can throw an exception here to indicate you do not support the given database type
Returns:
the database definition language string which will create the table for this persistent object to be stored in

makeDDLTypeMap

public static Map<String,String> makeDDLTypeMap(String fileName,
                                                String[] types)
This is a convenience method which assists in creating the ddl type map, it basically allows you to easily create the map if you have followed the convention of placing all your ddl files in folders which are equivalent to the name of the database type they are created for and named them all identically with a name which is similar to the

Parameters:
fileName - the name of the file (e.g. users.sql)
types - the types to include in the map, use the constants from DatabaseTranslator (e.g. "derby")
Returns:
the map which can be given to the setDBTypeToFile(Map) method

makeDDLMap

public static Map<String,String> makeDDLMap(String fileName,
                                            String[] dbTypes,
                                            String prefixPath)
Convenience method which will take a filename and an array of DBTYPE String constants (from DatabaseTranslator, example DatabaseTranslator.DBTYPE_MYSQL) and produce a map of standard DDL types to file paths
Will create a map like so: dbType -> [prefixPath/]dbType/fileName

Parameters:
fileName - the name of the sql file (e.g. myTableDDL.sql)
dbTypes - an array with 1 or more dbTypes which you have DDL files for
prefixPath - (optional) the prefix to append before the dbType and fileName (should not have a leading "/"), can be null or "" if npt used
Returns:
the map of dbType to file paths
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the filename or dbTYpes are null or empty
